description: ORDER granting 178 Motion for Leave, 179 Motion for Leave, and 180 Motion for Leave. Defendants claim that Plaintiffs have used generative artificial intelligence and cited non-existent or erroneous authorities in recent submissions to the Court. The Court has conducted an independent review and find that Plaintiffs' motions at CM/ECF 174, 175, 176, and 177 contain multiple citations that are incorrect, do not contain the quotes or content cited to, and reference cases that cannot be located and thus presumably do not exist. While the use of generative artificial intelligence is not forbidden, attorneys have a duty of competence to their clients and a duty of candor to the tribunal. The duty of competence requires "the legal knowledge, skill, thoroughness and preparation reasonably necessary for the representation." See Model Rule 1.1 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. The duty of candor toward the tribunal prohibits making false statements of law to the Court. See Model Rule 3.3 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. Plaintiffs shall have until March 25, 2025 to file a memorandum showing cause as to why sanctions should not be levied against them. Signed by Judge Raul M. Arias-Marxuach on 3/18/2025. (mrr) (Entered: 03/18/2025)

Order filed for PUBLICATION (RONALD M. GOULD, MARSHA S. BERZON and MORGAN B. CHRISTEN) This case is REMANDED to the district court for further proceedings consistent with the United States Supreme Court’s opinion in Gonzalez v. Google LLC, 143 S. Ct. 1191 (2023) (per curiam).
